column4: how can I change the default perms of a directory? For example, it seems that 755 is popular with new files/folders in linux. But I dont want that, I want 775 so ANYTHING created in that dir gets 775 perms. How can I do this?
changes permissions via terminal
sudo chmod 770 etc
not sure what's wrong with sudo
I dont want system wide. I just want it for 1 folder.
I guess I need windows-style openness with this share and it sucks when stuff is created in 755, requires me to have to reset perms just to keep working.
you want all current files/subfolder be 775 or the default permissions for future creating
I think you want ' chmod 2775 /path/to/foo'
if you only cares about the current files/subfolders, 'chmod -R 0775 /path/to/foo'
I don't understand - why are the perms you're giving me 4 digit instead of 3. why 0775, 2775, etc??
the '2' in '2775' means setgid for folder, you can set '4775' to setuid, and '1775' to set sticky, the system default /tmp should be 1777, for example
'man chmod' for more
are you saying with chmod 2775 I can sticky the 775 for ALL new files/folders created as 775? Or would that not do it?
yes, '2775' will do it for gid, if want uid be kept as well set it '6775', or even '7775'
going to test this now...
for example, the system /usr/src is set to '2775' by default
didnt work
because system default /etc/profile already sets 'umask 022', set 'umask 002' in your ~/.bashrc
it's simple, but probably not the way of simpleness you thought
have you tried 'umask 002'?
umask changes the entire system though, right
if you don't want security, make 'umask 000' globally in /etc/profile, and 'chmod 2775 /path/to/foo'
I want security of course...
if you want security, don't change /etc/profile, make it '~/.bash_profile'
